name: Dramatic Moments in Literature Trivia Quiz | Literature | 10 Questions

questions.text: In which of these novels does the protagonist NOT commit a murder?
questions.explanation:
'Of Human Bondage'.

	Dorian Gray kills his friend (and painter), Basil. Raskolnikov kills a pawnbroker in 'Crime and Punishment'. Meursault kills an Arab in 'Stranger'. In 'Bondage', one of the key characters dies - but not as a result of murder.

questions.text: In a play by Arthur Miller, the protagonist says: 'Sure he was my son. But I think to him they were all my sons'. What action follows this comment?
questions.explanation:
Suicide.

	The protagonist learns a terrible secret and commits suicide after being overwhelmed by guilt.

questions.text: What author wrote a poem in which a serviceman's participation in war is described as 'a lonely impulse of delight'?
questions.explanation:
W.B. Yeats

	'An Irish Airman Foresees His Death'. 'A lonely impulse of delight led to this tumult in the clouds ...'

questions.text: Thomas Hardy's novel, 'The Mayor of Casterbridge', deals with the theme of retribution. What sin was the protagonist guilty of committing?
options: Having an affair with a married woman
questions.explanation:
Selling his wife.

	Michael Henchard sells his wife. It comes back to haunt him.

questions.text: What author suggested an irrational basis for certain human behaviors in 'The Imp of the Perverse'?
questions.explanation:
Edgar Allan Poe.

	This story is interesting in that it seems to anticipate the idea of unconscious motivation as a powerful force in human behavior more than fifty years before Freud's writings.

questions.text: What document is written (in part) due to 'a decent respect to the opinions of mankind'?
options: Speech by Jefferson Davis upon becoming President of the Confederacy
questions.explanation:
Declaration of Independence.

	'When in the course of human events ... ' (etc.), it is appropriate to explain why a nation is separating itself from another nation (Great Britain).

questions.text: In which of his plays did Shakespeare observe that 'there are more things in heaven and earth ... than are dreamt of in your philosophy'?
Speaking of other-worldly matters, who said 'God is his own interpreter and he will make it plain'?
questions.explanation:
William Cowper.

	'Light Shining Out of the Darkness'. 'God moves in strange and wondrous ways ...'

questions.text: In which novel by Charles Dickens does a character intentionally sacrifice his life for another person?
questions.explanation:
A Tale of Two Cities.

	Charles Darnay and Sydney Carton. 'It is a far, far better thing I do ...'

questions.text: In a famous short story, a motive for murder is described as follows: 'Object there was none. Passion there was none. I loved the old man.' What story is this?
